newsitem.title: USA: PRESS DIGEST - New York Times business - Dec 26.
newsitem.headline: PRESS DIGEST - New York Times business - Dec 26.

text.p: The New York Times reported the following business stories on Thursday:

- Shoney's, the big restaurant chain which settled one of the nation's largest racial descrimination lawsuits in 1992, is at the centre of a debate between large investors and the SEC over shareholder resolutions about workplace issues.
- The DC-9 that crached near Miami in May was owned and operated by ValuJet Inc, but Tower Air, a different low-fare airline, says it is still struggling to recover from the crash.
- A group of reports from foreign countries shows the American trend of returning up to 12 percent of purchased goods is one consumer trend that has not been exported.
- Japan's Cabinet approved a budget proposal for the next fiscal year that would raise the consumption tax but would still fall short of hopes for austerity measures to cut the defecit.
- Japan's Prime Minister approved a proposal to reform the Finance Ministry.
- Federal regulators, moving to reduce the fees regional telephone companies charge to connect long-distance calls, said they might let the industry lower the charges gradually, without a timetable.
- Though stock markets were closed in most of the world, share prices bounced back on Christmas Day in Japan.
- Banc One has abandoned a plan that would have allowed consumers to use credit cards to borrow as much as $10,000 against their 401(k) retirement funds.

- As managed care is being criticised for cutting hospital stays short and penalising doctors who order expensive procedures, a legislative committee in Connecticut has found that managed care seems to be reducing health care costs while satisfying consumers.
- Robert Citron, former treasurer of Orange County, Calif., could end up picking up roadside trash instead of going to jail.
